div.note:
“To day we pass the Alps” (MS IA, g.2; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—The Ruskin family approached the Alps for the first time from the north, traveling from Schaffhausen and Constance, and they crossed into Italy through the Via Mala and the Splügen Pass (see Tour of 1833).
To describe the approach and crossing, Ruskin intended, according to his Plan for Continuation of the Account of a Tour on the Continent, to situate “Passing the Alps” at the start of a cluster of poems and/or prose pieces about the experience of crossing the Alps, several of which he did draft in verse: “Passing the Alps”, “Via Mala”, “Splugen”, “The Summit”, “The Descent”, and “Italia, Italia”. As sections leading up to “Passing the Alps”, the plan lists “Schaffhausen”, “The Alps,” “The Fall of the Rhine,” “Constance,” “Werdenberg, and “Pfaffers.”
Ruskin models this arrangement on Italy by Samuel Rogers (1763–1855), in which a poem about the western Alpine pass, “The Great St. Bernard,” gives way to “The Descent,” followed by “The Alps.” In the latter poem, Rogersʼs speaker retraces imaginatively the entire span of the crossing, preparing for his celebration of arrival in the following poems about Italy. (Also, between “The Descent” and “The Alps,” Rogers pauses to relate two verse tales: “Jorasse,” a highland tale about an intrepid Alpine hunter; and “Marguerite de Tours,” a lowland tale about a girl who crosses from Martigny, on the Swiss side of the St. Bernard, to the opposite vale of Aosta in order to attend to her dying father. In the 1839 edition, Rogers added a third tale, “The Brothers,” about twin brothers who lose their infant brother to an eagle.)
In Ruskinʼs plan for the “Account,” he makes “Passing the Alps” serve the structural function of Rogersʼs “The Alps” as a summary reflection on the experience of crossing. Both poems use a trope of the Alps as a “barrier” between civilizations, a trope developed by a historical reference to Hannibal as the sublime analogy for struggling against that barrier (Hannibalʼs crossing is also the subject of Turnerʼs vignette for “The Alps” in the 1830 illustrated Italy). Thus, Ruskin captures Rogersʼs idea of one poem serving as an epitome of the experience of crossing that is elaborated—topographically, historically, anecdotally—in surrounding poems.
There are also differences between Ruskinʼs and Rogersʼs crossing poems. In “Passing the Alps”, Ruskin develops the vision of Hannibalʼs invasion as its sole topic, whereas in “The Alps” Rogers characteristically contrasts the turbulent past with his speakerʼs present “path of pleasure” (Rogers, Italy [1830], 30). Also, Ruskin, according to his plan, intended to situate “Passing the Alps” at the head of a cluster of poems about the mountain pass, unlike Rogers who posed “The Alps” as a retrospection past the watershed. Despite these differences, Ruskin clearly adopted structural cues from Rogersʼs sequence of poems.
According to this interpretation, W. G. Collingwood violated Ruskinʼs structural intentions. As the first editor to reconstruct the “Account” by appending draft to Ruskinʼs MS IX fair copy, Collingwood erred by placing “Passing the Alps” between “Genoa” and “Chamouni”, causing Ruskinʼs poem to function as a transition between Italy and Switzerland, rather than between Germany and Italy. The latter arrangement appears to have been in Ruskinʼs mind as early as the MS IA, g.2 sequence, which pairs “Passing the Alps” with “Milan Cathedral”.
In another view, however, Collingwoodʼs erroneous placement of “Passing the Alps” was inspired, for while he disrupted Ruskinʼs elaboration of Rogersʼs model, the editor used available materials to patch together an approximation of how Ruskinʼs cluster of poems about the north crossing would eventually have been mirrored by a cluster about the western crossing. According to Ruskinʼs plan, the Splügen cluster, extending from “Passing the Alps” through “The Descent” and poems on the Italian lakes, would have been mirrored in reverse by a cluster including “The Ascent” and “The Grand St. Bernard,” leading to “The Lake of Geneva”—and doubtless this cluster, too, would have exploited Rogersʼs tropes about crossings. Thus, Collingwoodʼs solution reveals another way in which Ruskin abandoned “The Account” only when he had effectively completed his apprenticeship to his models (see Account of a Tour on the Continent: Discussion—Sources). Moreover, Collingwoodʼs “misplacement” allows “Passing the Alps” to stand in for “The Grand St. Bernard,” which Ruskin never composed, by associating the reference to Hannibalʼs crossing with a western passage where the event belongs historically.
“The barrier of boundless length” (MS IA, g.2; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—Cf. “To me they [the Alps] seemed the barriers of a world” (Rogers, Italy (1830), 30).
“The Queen of nations” (MS IA, g.2; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—Ancient Rome.

“The Carthaginian foe . . . Avalanches roar” (MS IA, g.2; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—In 218 BC, near the start of the Second Punic War between Carthage and Rome, the Carthaginian leader, Hannibal, led his army on an unprecedented march across the Alps, invading Italy and surprising Rome via a western passage somewhere in present‐day Piedmont.
“Cannæs plain” (MS IA, g.2; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—An area in Apulia, in southeast Italy, where Hannibalʼs army won a major victory over a large Roman force in 216 BC.
